bibl.title: Letter from Morris Fishbein to George A. Kellogg, July 25, 1941

div1.p: Fishbein discusses publication of Hench's article in "Hygeia," and informs Kellogg that they wish to include a colored insert.

div1.head: Letter from Morris Fishbein to George A. Kellogg, July 25, 1941
div1.opener:
C O P Y
HYGEIA
535 North Dearborn
Chicago, Ill.
July 25, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
Dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p: I appreciate very much indeed your letter of July 22.

I believe it would be well worth while for us to withhold
publication of the article by Doctor Hench for another month
if necessary in order to have you provide us with enough inserts
in four colors of the Cornwell painting so that one would be
available to every reader of Hygeia. We will, of course, be
glad indeed to credit the Wyeth Company for these plates and to
recognize fully the contribution.

We will also be quite willing to provide you with as many
reprints as you may care to order of the article as it appears
in HYGEIA, including also with these reprints the 4-color repro-
duction.

We would hope with the article to give the story of the
painting as it appeared in the New York Mirror on page 11. In
fact, I believe we could reproduce that page in HYGEIA just as
it is in the Mirror. I am sure they would be willing to give
us permission.

Please let me know whether or not you can provide the
necessary inserts and about when we could expect to receive them.
I will then notify our Circulation Department, so I will know how
many ought to be prepared.
